choices.text: Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present
Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy attends the surgery OPD without an adult accompanying him. He has a sore throat. Legally, a general practitioner must:
questions.solution:
Minimum age at which a person can give consent:

  1. 12 years:-
    1. General physical examination (Doctor can prescribe medications as appropriate)
    2. Examination of a Sexual assault victim
  2. 18 years-
    1. Surgeries
    2. General Anaesthesia
    3. Medical Termination of Pregnancy
    4. Live donor for organ transplantation
    5. Sexual intercourse (girl should be minimum 18 years)

12 years (As per Sec 89 IPC)
18 years (As per Sec 87 IPC)

questions.text: According MCI regulation, medical education granted by Indian universities comes under:
questions.solution: Schedule III contains only those qualifications which are not mentioned in Schedule I and II. So the answer is Schedule I.

questions.text: Transplantation of human organs act was passed by government of India in
questions.solution:
The TRANSPLANTATION OF HUMAN ORGANS ACT (THOA) 1994.It provides for the regulation of removal, storage and transplantation of human organs for therapeutic purposes for the prevention of commercial dealings in human organs. It defines transplantation as a means of grafting of any human organs from any living person or deceased to some other living person for therapeutic purposes. No organ is to be removed from the body of a person in the event of his brain stem death unless such death is certified by a board of medical experts.

In amendments the term organ is substituted with human organs and tissues.

Latest amendments were done in 2013

Reference: MODI'S MEDICAL JURISPRUDENCE AND TOXICOLOGY 23rd EDITION Pg250, 251 Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th edition Dr P C Ignatius Pg. 480

questions.text: Registered medical practitioner taking assistance to treat a patient from someone who has no medical qualification is known as:
questions.solution:
Doctor should not take assistance from someone who has no medical qualification to attend, treat, or perform operation, which is called covering.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th edition Dr P C Ignatius Pg. 466

questions.text: Davidson body is used to determine?
questions.solution: X chromosome can be demonstrated in cells by staining methods. This is called sex chromatin and if it is present, the person is said to be chromatin positive. Sex chromatin is seen in polymorphs as a drum stick from a lobe of the nucleus. It is called DAVIDSON BODY. They are absent in males.

questions.text: In the case of criminal negligence, punishment is given by?
questions.solution:
Punishment for professional negligence (malpractice) is given only by criminal courts. Criminal courts are magistrate courts, session courts, high courts and supreme court.

Civil and consumer courts are for compensation in professional negligence (not for punishment).

questions.text: A patient died and it was proved that it was due to negligence of doctor. The doctor can be prosecuted and charged in criminal court under section 304A IPC if:
questions.solution:
Criminal negligence is violation of law. There is gross negligence or lack of competency. There is imprisonment, fine or both.

Medical negligence is absence of skill and care. Punishment is compensation, fine or imprisonment.

Civil negligence: simple absence of skill and care. Trial conduct in civil court, consumer court

RES ISPA LOQUITUR means the thing speaks for itself.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th edition Dr P C Ignatius Pg.

questions.text: Schedule-3 of MCI includes?
questions.solution: Schedule 1 of Indian Medical Council Act contains recognised medical qualifications granted by universities in India, Schedule 2 contains those granted outside India, first part of Schedule 3 contains those granted by medical institutions not included in first schedule and second part contains those granted outside India but not included in second schedule.

choices.text: Deserves to be acquitted on the strength of evidence

questions.text: A quack gives a penicillin injection to a patient who dies due to it. Will the quack be relieved for his criminal responsibility by raising a plea of the accident?
questions.solution: Most likely the patient has died due to hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin (anaphylaxis). Before giving penicillin's, sensitivity testing is indicated, which is not done by quack in this case. So he is responsible for criminal negligence.

questions.text: Leaving (or forgetting) an instrument or sponge in the abdomen of the patient during a surgery and closing the operation is?
questions.solution: Leaving (or forgetting) an instrument or sponge in the abdomen of the patient during a surgery and closing the abdomen at operation amounts to criminal negligence.

questions.text: Contributory negligence is negligence due to?
questions.solution: Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct, or absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient, or his personal attendant, which combined with the doctor's negligence, contributed to the injury complained of, as a direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred. – KSN Reddy

choices.text: Police not below the level of sub inspector

questions.text: In civil negligence, onus of proof lies on?
questions.solution: Generally, the innocence of doctor is assumed and in cases where negligence is alleged, the plantiff (patient or relative) has to establish the guilt of the doctor. The patient is expected to prove that the doctor was negligent. Therefore, on us (responsibility) of proof lies on patient.

choices.text: On demand by court of law
If doctor discloses for protecting interest of the community

questions.text: Professional secrecy can be divulged?
questions.solution:
Doctor is obliged to keep as secrets all that he comes to know about his patient during treatment. He has to keep those things confidential. But, he can reveal certain facts about a patient to protect the interest of the public or state. There is no professional secrecy when court asks to disclose information.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th edition Dr P C Ignatius Pg473-474

questions.text: A newspaper editor discloses the identity of a victim of rape without prior permission. He would be tried under which of the following IPC sections?
questions.solution: S.228A IPC- Disclosure of identity of the victim of Rape with punishment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: Doctrine of res ipsa loquitur means ?
questions.solution:
The doctrine of res ipsa loquitur It means the thing or fact speaks for itself In a case of professional negligence of a physician, the patient need not prove negligence. It is applied when the following conditions are fulfilled :

i. That is the absence of negligence the injury would not have occurred ordinarily.

ii. That the doctor had exclusive control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.

iii. That the patient was not guilty of contributory negligence.

questions.text: Under IPC a person below ____ years is not criminally responsible?
questions.solution:
82 IPC: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child <7 years of age.

83 IPC: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child between 7-12 years age, who has not attained sufficient maturity to understand the nature and consequences of his conduct.

As per the above two sections, below 7 years of age a person can never be punished. Between 7-12 years the child can be punished if he commits an offence unless it can be proved that the child was not mature enough.

choices.text: Culpable homicide not amounting to murder-304 IPC

questions.text: Which is false?
questions.solution:
IPC SECTIONS RELATED TO MURDER, SUICIDE etc.

Culpable homicide, definition.

Murder, definition

302. Punishment for murder

304. Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder

304A. Causing death by negligence, punishment upto 2 years.

304B. Dowry death, punishment upto 7 years.

305. Abetment of suicide of child or insane person

306. Abetment of suicide

307. Attempt to murder

308. Attempt to commit culpable homicide

309. Attempt to commit suicide

S.309 IPC is no more punishable as per Mental Health Care Act 2017

questions.text: Maximum Punishment under 304A IPC?
questions.solution: 304A IPC (causing death by Negligence): Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished up to two years, or with fine, or with both.

questions.text: Mr.X fired his gun at Mr.Y who moved and escaped with the bullet only grazing his thigh. There was only a little bleeding and no other significant injury. Mr. X is liable for arrest under which section of IPC?
questions.solution:
In the question there is simple injury by a dangerous weapon, hence 324 IPC

IPC Sections related to Hurt etc:-

319 Definition of Hurt (Any Bodily pain, Infirmity or Disease)

320 Definition of Grievous hurt.

321 Defines Voluntarily causing hurt

322 Defines Voluntarily causing Grievous hurt

323 Punishment for causing hurt: Up to 01 year, fine up to 1000 Rs

324 Punishment for causing Hurt by dangerous weapon: Up to 03 years, or fine

325 Punishment for causing Grievous hurt: Up to 07 years, and also fine.

326 Punishment for Grievous hurt by dangerous weapons: Imprisonment for life, or up to 10 yrs, and fine

326A Causing grievous hurt by throwing acid: Minimum ten years and maximum upto life

326B Attempting to throw acid: Minimum 5 years and maximum upto 7 years

330 Causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property.

331 Causing grievous hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property.

334 Punishment for Hurt on provocation: Up to 01 month, or with fine up to 500 rupees, or both.

335 Punishment for Grievous hurt on provocation: Up to 04 years or with fine up to 2000 rupees

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic assaults neighbour. He had quit drinking 4 days back - now has delirium tremens. He is:
questions.solution:
Delirium Tremens:It occurs in the chronic alcoholics due to sudden withdrawl of alcohol. It typically begins 72-96 hrs after the last drink. Features:

- Tendency to commit suicide, homicide or violent assault or to cause damage to the property

- Disorientation to time and place and a peculiar kind of delirium of horrors owing to hallucinations of the sight and hearing

Delirium is considered unsoundness of mind and not intoxication, so section 84 IPC will be applied instead of 86 IPC.

Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind is not an offence

Section 85 IPC: Offence caused after Involuntary intoxication is not an offence

Section 86 IPC: Offence caused after Voluntary intoxication is an offence

questions.text: The application of medical knowledge for the purpose of law and administration of justice is called
questions.solution:
1. Forensic Medicine: The application of medical knowledge for the purpose of law and administration of justice. E.g. Doctor doing an autopsy to find the cause and manner of death helps police officer to solve the crime
  2. Medical Jurisprudence: Legal Principles that guide Medical Professional. For e.g. Laws related to medical negligence. Violation of these legal principles can be punishable under the law
  3. Medical ethics: deals with the moral principles that guide the members of medical profession when they deal with each other, their patients as well as with the State. For e.g. a doctor is not expected to ask for a 'cut' from his colleague, to whom he refers his patient for some special investigation. Violation of Medical ethics may not be punishable under law, but can be punished by state medical council
  4. Medical Etiquette: They are the conventional law of courtesy to be observed among the members of medical profession. For instance, a doctor is not expected to charge for giving medical advice to another doctor. Violation of Medical ettiquetes is neither punishable under law nor by state medical council

questions.text: Punishment for false medical certificate:
questions.solution:
197 IPC defines punishment given for issuing false certificates. Here the punishment is same as that of giving any False evidence (perjury) in the court, i.e. 193 IPC (upto 7 years) and fine and erasure of name from medical register

Please note below the IPC related to false evidence:

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years.

questions.text: Which section defines perjury?
questions.solution:
Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth.

IPC related to false evidence:

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years.

It is important to note that the term Perjury is nowhere mentioned in Indian Law. Concerned sections deal with False Evidence.

questions.text: A woman died within 5 years of marriage under suspicious circumstances. Her parents complained that her in laws used to frequently demand for dowry. Her autopsy will be done under:
questions.solution:
Autopsy is compulsory in dowry death cases (Sec. 174 Cr.PC).Autopsy of the dead body should be conducted by two doctors, in case of death of women within 7 yrs. of marriage, or women aged below 30 yrs.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th edition Dr P C Ignatius Pg. 448

questions.text: Which of the following is used for narcoanalysis
questions.solution:
Narco Analysis

1) In the Narco Analysis Test, the subject's imagination is neutralized by making him semi-conscious by some drug. In this state, it becomes difficult for him to lie and his answers would be restricted to facts he is already aware of.

2)Drugs used for narco analysis: Scopolamine, sodium amytal, sodium pentothal, Sodium Seconal

questions.text: If death occurs in police custody, it would be investigated by
questions.solution:
Please remember that Custodial death is the only condition where inquest is mandatory to be done only by judicial Magistrate. In India two types of Inquest are held- Police and Magistrate. Magistrate inquest is of further two types- Executive magistrate and judicial Magistrate.

Inquest Sections:

1) 174 CrPc: Police Inquest (It is the commonest inquest and Done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc)

2) 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest. It is of two types:

  1. Executive Magistrate:
    1. Dowry Death
    2. Exhumation.
  2. Judicial Magistrate:Custodial Deaths

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted only in:
questions.solution: Dying Declaration is made to judicial Magistrate or Medical Officer. It can also be recorded by village headman or police, but, its evidential value becomes less.

questions.text: If a patient survives after having given dying declaration then it stands as
questions.solution:
If victim survives after giving dying declarartion, the recorded statement will not have much value. Victim will have to give oral evidence in court. At the maximum the statement will have some corroborative value.

Whereas, If victim died after giving dying deposition, the recorded statement will have complete value

choices.text: Death of a person in police custody
Dowry deaths within 5 years of marriage

questions.text: In India magistrate inquest is done in the following cases except
questions.solution:
Inquest is legal inquiry into cause of death where death is apparently not due to natural causes.

In India, in most cases (whether suicide, murder or accident) the inquest is done by police (under section174 Crpc).

Magistrate inquest is done in only three conditions (under section 176 Crpc):

By Executive Magistrate: 

1) Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage

2) Exhumation

By Judicial Magistrate:

3) Custodial Deaths

questions.text: Hemoperfusion with charcoal is useful in poisoning with
questions.solution: Extracorporeal Techniques like Hemodialysis, charcoal hemoperfusion and hemofiltration are used only for a limited number of opoisons.
